review_title: Good with potential to be great
pros: Lots of polarizing opinions here, huh? Many good people work here, all who have the best intentions of making people’s lives better. Great benefits and more than just your typical health and dental. I have never paid less for glasses and contacts than I have since being with NLCS because of how good our vision plan is. During covid they very proactively pushed out additional mental health resources. Very generous PTO. I prefer working remote so I’m happy about the decision to move the office and create a space you can drop in when needed. I’ve gotten so much more time back to focus on my home life and well being with not having to commute every day.
cons: If you’re anti covid, anti mask, anti vaccine, this might not be the place for you (I love and support nlcs for this and don’t consider it a con but shockingly to me, many do). There isn’t a much room for advancement in roles, but they will support training for skills you want to grow. Things feel a bit chaotic right now but I think that is what is happening everywhere. Definitely some favoritism happens at the leadership level. The biggest con for me is how slowly NLCS moves in every aspect of business. I am especially looking forward to the DEI program becoming more expansive than it is right now, especially in regards to sexuality and gender identity. NLCS has an opportunity as a Lutheran organization (one of the few Christian denominations that supports and teaches acceptance of this community) to lead the way for how Protestant Christian organizations can become a safe space for LGBTQAI+ residents and staff and where they can be their authentic selves, but it’s moving so slowly.

pros:
- There are good people within the organization 
- Depending on department - good work life balance.
- Benefits weren't terrible.
cons:
- Compensation is below average. I was able to receive a 25% pay increase after moving into a similar job role. 
- Terrible financial decisions by corporate. Saving money seems to be the only goal at this point. The company is bleeding and the ripple effects have been felt across the board. Decisions are made at the expense of residents and employees. Resident care is severely lacking and the refusal to make any sort of life improvements are all due to budget. Lack of competitive pay, benefit cuts, axing of departments, outsourcing of the IT team - this one is completely asinine. The community I worked at can tell you first hand how bad support has gotten. 
- Unable to keep good and talented individuals. Great employees leave because leadership fails to cultivate a good work culture. 
- DEI is a joke. 
- Little room for career growth.

pros: Departmental leadership was fantastic. My Director and Manager always fought for me and the team. Encouraged growth and helped foster career progression where-ever they were able. I could tell they always looked out for my best interest and because of that it helped me to try and go the extra mile because I knew I'd get recognized internally and it helped to shape my role in mentoring newer team members. Even after my departure, I still regularly have conversations with my former supervisors because they are still so heavily invested in my well being and growth as a person and individual in my career.
cons: It's surprising to me that NLCS is still "afloat." The senior leadership doesn't seem to care much about investing resources in necessary business related expenses and it's very clear that any of the changes in policy benefits no one except their own. I've never seen a company that struggles to retain their employees so poorly and it's not surprising to see the good employees leaving at such a rapid pace leaving inexperienced employees in their stead. I'm not quite sure what the numbers are, but I can't imagine the retention rate of employees being over 50%. The compensation is also atrocious. In 2 weeks of searching for another job, I was able to find another company that offered more than 30% increase of my salary. This seems to be a general theme I found when discussing with former colleagues who have also left. You will need a direct supervisor who can negotiate on your behalf to get an even small percentage of what your market value is. NLCS boasts their partnership with an outside company who helps to research what salaries their employees have but it's clearly not working as it seems like neither inflation nor job skills are taken into account for this "raise."

review_title: Used to be great, now ok, lots of room for improvement
pros: Great benefits and amount of time off. Access to training opportunities. Gives you the opportunity to work with residents who have amazing life stories. Residents are the best part of the job.
cons: Over the past few years there has been a significant culture shift. New CEO is doing well and filling big shoes well, but some of the executive team is problematic. We seem to have moved to a place where all we care about is saving money, often at the expense of residents care and raising their fees astronomically. It's also almost impossible to get rid of dead weight that brings the organization down. All the good employees get totally burnt out trying to fill in for others and end up leaving.

pros: Nice, intelligent coworkers who genuinely care about the mission of the company.  No micromanaging supervisors.  CEO is extremely personable, friendly, respectful, and fair.
cons:
Salaries are lacking unless you're in IT or the head of the department simply cares enough to pay their people what they're worth so they'll stay.  You work hard for pennies on your paycheck in most departments but that fact is easily overlooked by many because of the great work being done.  There is no structure for salary ranges and no rhyme or reason as to which positions are exempt versus non exempt.  Raises are negligible; laughable even.  Meaningless positions are created far too often.  Some work extremely hard for little pay. Some don't have much to do with more pay.

Poor and egregious behavior is overlooked and excused for some employees while others are reprimanded or even terminated for minor, petty issues.

Benefits are decent, however a little expensive compared to other companies.

Overall, money is SPENT in certain departments and it shows, while being pinched in others, so great employees have lowered morale because of it.
